88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:45): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, is the author of document.php a big fan of GUIDs and thinks it's easier to use SHA512 than figure out MAC addresses or such?  Or maybe they just want really secure content-addressable storage?
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (23:56): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Whirlpool hash, actually.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (23:57): And I'm the author.  Woo!
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:00): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb_, so why are you using 512-bit hashes for id's?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:01): he's VERY prolific
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): Y'know I was just about to ask that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:02): hint: if it's longer than the hash you get when you check it into your VCS, it's too long :)
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:02): Because shrug, that's why.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:02): to use up the entire address space over 100 years of blogging, you'd have to blog at a rate of 4.2 x 10^144 Hz
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:03): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, well, git uses SHA1, which isn't advisable if you want actual security . . .
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:03): that is an INSANE frequency
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, but only the square root of that to have a high chance of collision, right?  That's much more reasonable.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:04): um, even to avoid a collision, if you were to have that frequency as EM waves, it'd still be 40 orders of magnitude narrower wavelength than the width of an atom
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:05): Well, so you can just write a lot of blog posts in parallel.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:05): A million monkeys and all.  Or 10^60 monkeys, whatever it takes.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:05): Dude, I coded my document writer in like 10 minutes.  I had just used whirlpool for something else, because it's fun, so it was on my mind.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:05): (I'm not sure there's enough mass in the observable universe to create 10^60 monkeys.)
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:05): They'd have to be very small monkey, but you could.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:06): very small
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:06): there's only ~10^80 atoms in the visible universe
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:06): and most of that is hydrogen
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:06): not so useful for making monkeys
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:07): http://www.guzer.com/pictures/very-small-monkey.jpg ?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:08): You could use the hydrogen to make inflatable monkeys
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:08): there's about 10^27 atoms in that monkey assuming he's about 1kg
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:09): That looks like a heck of a lot less than 1 kg.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:09): Hmm, maybe not so much less.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:09): so that's 10^53 monkeys max
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:09): Yes,  by "very small" I meant "microscopic".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:09): I dunno, I'm not a primatologist.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:09): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb_, it has to be big enough to type blog posts at random, otherwise it won't work.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:10): By the time I'm converting the mass of the universe into monkeys, I think I can devise alternate typing methods.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:10): How much entropy does a typical monkey contain?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:10): also alternate hashing methods
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:11): Yeah, it'd probably be relatively easy to switch to a 1024-bit hash, if you have the resources to make that many monkeys.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:15): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb_: You know when the TAG said URLs were opaque identifiers you weren't supposed to take it as a commandment to make them as opaque as possible
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:16): WELL MAYBE THEY SHOULDN'T HAVE SUGGESTED IT THEN.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:16): sulks.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:16): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: How do you know we weren't supposed to?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:18): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, that's not as opaque as possible.  It has "document.php" in it.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:20): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: That's why I provided the more opaque but less entropic link /:gg5
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:20): "less entropic"?
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:20): lower entropy
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:21): i was constrained in my wording by parallelism.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:21): more/less
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:22): How is it lower-entropy?
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:22): Less possible states.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:28): What's your definition of microstates and macrostates here?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (00:28): Back
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:28): waves hands wildly.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:28): I mean, you say a macrostate is low-entropy if there are few microstates corresponding to it.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:29): I really don't have a sufficient background to properly defend my statement.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (00:32): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb_ I'll try to have that html5 ie print thing shared soon enough.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (00:32): I hope I don't come across like a dick, I just want to give something that has had some testing.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:32): Man, whatever, dick.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (00:32): pfft.

171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:36): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I'll note that the urls are much better for me.  The one I share is specifically made to be unguessable.  I just go a little overboard with it.  ^_^
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:37): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb_: Why do you want an unguessable URL?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:38): I mean isn't it easier just to set up authentication?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:39): It seems easier to leak a URL
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:40): (becasue you give it to someone, they link to it, google finds it, and you have lost)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:40): (whereas if you give them a username / password they implicitly understand it is supposed to be private)
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:42): That's fine.  Once I've given it to someone, I obviously want it to be findable.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:43): I have occasionally given out links to people that I did not want to be public (or, sometimes, they did not want to be public)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:43): once saw a site that encrypted a password plus today's date rounded to 6 months, to generate a URL for a private page
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:44): and if you got the wrong password then you'd get the wrong URL, and if you had the URL then it'd only be valid for 6 months
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:44): but I could find a few of those 6-month URLs since they'd leaked out onto Google
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:45): and (since the encryption algorithm wasn't very good) use them to work out the password
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:45): which then allowed access to the most recent page
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:45): So I don't really buy the idea that everything shared is implicitly public
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:46): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: You don't have to.  I was expressing my own feelings on content that I share.  ^_^
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:47): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb_: Just don't be surprised if this happens every time you share a link :)
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Was it actually encrypted, or just hashed?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (01:47): Where by "this" I mean an inquisition about your URL scheme
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:47): Also, that seems pretty bad, since you have to prevent password collisions, and thus leak information about other pages on the system.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:48): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: That's why I need to remember to share my shorturls instead.  ^_^
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:48): Also, why I need to finally sit down and build myself a proper blogging platform out of the tools I have lying around.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:48): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb_: It was some rubbish JS hash-like algorithm
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:49): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Ah, homerolled crypto.  Nice.
